snippet: His chances of victory are minuscule, but he and other hard-right candidates will still be a headache for the G.O.P. in the 2016 primaries. Can mainstream Republicans stop him? Should they try?
abstract: Ben Carson, pediatric neurosurgeon who burst on to the political scene in 2013 as a controversial novelty, is now looking to be seen as a serious Republican contender for 2016 presidential nomination; hard-right candidacy like Carson's presents new kind of challenge to GOP, which has been selecting establishment nominees since at least 1980.
lead_paragraph: His chances of victory are minuscule, but he and other hard-right candidates will still be a headache for the G.O.P. in the 2016 primaries. Can mainstream Republicans stop him? Should they try?

headline.main: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Ben Carson?
